Brief Hospital Course:
___ w/ a history of DLBCL, who presents with dyspnea and hypoxic 
respiratory failure as a transfer from OSH, course complicated 
by fever, shock, and status epilepticus. 

ACUTE ISSUES
# Hypoxic respiratory failure
Patient had fever at OSH and evidence of PNA on exam per 
records, and with increasing cough per history possibly element 
of PNA. Given ceftriaxone and azithro initially, but as no 
fevers, WBC, productive cough, or evidence of focal 
consolidation on CXR here, so antibiotics were initially 
stopped. However, she later developed fevers, leukocytosis, and 
hypotension, concerning for sepsis, so broad spectrum 
antibiotics were restarted. CT torso did not show sign of 
infection, but given critical illness she was continued on broad 
spectrum antibiotics with cefepime transitioned to Zosyn given 
concerns that Cefepime had lead to altered mental status.  

# Status Epilepticus
On ___ AM, due to persistent and profound encephalopathy, EEG 
was obtained, showing she was ___ status epilepticus.  Neurology 
was consulted, and the patient was loaded with Ativan and 
Keppra.  CT Head showed no interval change.  On ___ she 
continued to be ___ status epilepticus and was loaded on 
Phenytoin. She was then transferred back to the MICU. 
Ultimately, her seizures broke, but she never regained mental 
status. It was felt that the underlying etiology was rapid 
worsening of her lymphoma that invaded her CNS.

# Shock
# Fever
Requiring norepinephrine for hypotension initially. CVO2 75, so 
unlikely cardiogenic. Concerning for possible sepsis ___ setting 
of leukocytosis and fevers. On transfer back to the ICU patient 
again had a small pressor requirement. Given her persistent 
fevers a CT a/p was done ___ to assess for other infection, and 
none was found, but adenopathy was noted. Heme/onc consulted 
given concern that fevers, lymphadenopathy seen on CT a/p, and 
pancytopenia could be related to lymphoma. On ___, she 
continued to have hypotension, requiring fluid boluses to 
maintain appropriate MAP.  Thus, transferred back to ICU on 
___. The patient had stable blood pressures when back ___ the 
ICU, but continued to spike fevers. These were felt to be due to 
her underlying likely malignancy.

# Lymphoma
Patient's family noted that when she had recurrence of lymphoma, 
she sometimes presented like this. "Other" cells noted on 
differential of WBC, which was reviewed by pathology and found 
to be atypical cells, likely ___ the setting of infection. A CT 
a/p was done ___ to assess for other infection, and none was 
found. Heme/onc consulted given concern that fevers, 
lymphadenopathy seen on CT a/p, and pancytopenia could be 
related to relapse of lymphoma. ___ was consulted for LN biopsy. 
Ultimately, lymph node biopsy preliminary pathology was 
consistent with high grade lymphoma recurrence. As per the 
patient's outpatient oncologist, lymphoma had likely infiltrated 
her lungs, CNS, and bone marrow. She was ultimately made DNR/DNI 
and comfort measures only. She passed away on ___.

#Afib
Held home metoprolol and continued apixaban at first.  Apixaban 
stopped on ___ given need for LP to work up encephalopathy.
